description: wordsegment is an apache licensed module for english word segmentation written in pure python and based on a trillion word corpus based on code from the chapter natural language corpus data by peter norvig from the book beautiful data segaran and hammerbacher data file are derived from the google web trillion word corpus a described by thorsten brant and alex franz and distributed by the linguistic data consortium this module contains only a subset of that data the unigram data includes only the most common word similarly bigram data includes only the most common phrase every word and phrase is lowercased with punctuation removed pure pythonfully documented test coverageincludes unigram and bigram datacommand line interface for batch processingeasy to hack e g different scoring new data different language developed on python tested on cpython and pypy pypy tested on window mac o x and linuxtested using travis ci and appveyor ciinstalling wordsegment is simple with pip you can access documentation in the interpreter with python s built in help function in your own python program you ll mostly want to use segment to divide a phrase into a list of it part the load function read and par the unigrams and bigram data from disk loading the data only need to be done once wordsegment also provides a command line interface for batch processing this interface accepts two argument in file and out file line from in file are iteratively segmented joined by a space and written to out file input and output default to stdin and stdout respectively if you want to run wordsegment a a kind of server process then use python s u option for unbuffered output you can also set pythonunbuffered in the environment the maximum segmented word length is character neither the unigram nor bigram data contain word exceeding that length the corpus also excludes punctuation and all letter have been lowercased before segmenting text clean is called to transform the input to a canonical form sometimes it interesting to explore the unigram and bigram count themselves these are stored in python dictionary mapping word to count above we see that the spelling gray is more common than the spelling grey bigram are joined by a space some bigram begin with s this is to indicate the start of a bigram the unigrams and bigram data is stored in the wordsegment directory in the unigrams txt and bigram txt file respectively word segment api referenceusing a different corpuspython load dict fast from filewordsegment documentationwordsegment at pypiwordsegment at githubwordsegment issue trackercopyright grant jenkslicensed under the apache license version the license you may not use this file except in compliance with the license you may obtain a copy of the description: youtokentome is an unsupervised text tokenizer focused on computational efficiency it currently implement fast byte pair encoding bpe sennrich et al our implementation is much faster in training and tokenization than hugging face fastbpe and sentencepiece in some test case it is time faster check out our benchmark result key advantage extra feature a well a in the algorithm from the original paper ours doe not consider token that cross word boundary just like in sentencepiece all space symbol were replaced by meta symbol u it allows sequence of token to be converted back to text and for word boundary to be restored for example the phrase blazingly fast tokenization can be tokenized into bl az ingly fast token ization let s start with a self contained example train bpe model and save to file args return class youtokentome bpe with the loaded model class constructor load the trained model class youtokentome bpe ha the following method args return if output type is equal to youtokentome outputtype id or youtokentome outputtype subword then a list of list of integer or list of list of string will be returned respectively return a list vocab size string the i th string in the list corresponds to i th subword return int size of vocabulary args return integer from the range vocab size id of subword or if there is no such subword in the vocabulary unk id will be returned args return string subword from vocabulary by id convert each id to subword and concatenate with space symbol args return list of string youtokentome support the following command command bpe allows you to train byte pair encoding model based on a text file apply bpe encoding for a corpus of sentence use stdin for input and stdout for output by default encoding work in parallel using n thread description: this repository contains code and pre trained weight for transformer protein language model from facebook ai research including our state of the art esm and esmfold a well a msa transformer esm v for predicting variant effect and esm if for inverse folding transformer protein language model were introduced in the preprint of the paper biological structure and function emerge from scaling unsupervised learning to million protein sequence rives et al esm outperforms all tested single sequence protein language model across a range of structure prediction task esmfold harness the esm language model to generate accurate structure prediction end to end directly from the sequence of a protein for a complete list of available model with detail and release note see pre trained model comparison to related protein language model on structure prediction task a a prerequisite you must have pytorch installed to use this repository you can use this one liner for installation using the latest release of esm to use the esmfold model make sure you start from an environment with python and pytorch installed then add the esmfold option to your pip install which will install the dependency for openfold automatically openfold installation requires nvcc note if openfold installation fails please double check that nvcc is available and that a cuda compatable version of pytorch ha been installed alternatively we provide the esmfold conda environment which can be built via conda env create f environment yml we also support pytorch hub which remove the need to clone and or install this repository yourself after pip install you can load and use a pretrained model a follows after installing with the esmfold option you can use the esmfold structure prediction model a follows besides esm pretrained esmfold v which is the best performing model we recommend using we also provide esm pretrained esmfold v which wa used for the experiment in lin et al we also provide a script script esmfold inference py that efficiently predicts structure in bulk from a fasta file using esmfold this can be run withthe script will make one prediction for every sequence in the fasta file multimers can be predicted and should be entered in the fasta file a a single sequence with chain seprated by a character by default prediction will be batched together so that shorter sequence are predicted simultaneously this can be disabled by setting max token per batch batching can significantly improve prediction speed on shorter sequence the cpu offload flag can be useful for making prediction on longer sequence it will attempt to offload some parameter to the cpu ram rather than storing on gpu we provide a script that efficiently extract embeddings in bulk from a fasta file a cuda device is optional and will be auto detected the following command extract the final layer embedding for a fasta file from the esm model directory some protein emb esm now contains one pt file per fasta sequence use torch load to load them script extract py ha flag that determine what s included in the pt file if you want to load very large model like b and or do inference on long sequence on your machine regular gpu inference may lead to oom error we show how to load the model with fairscale s fully sharded data parallel fsdp and use it cpu offloading feature this allows to do inference of large model on a single gpu please check out example esm infer fairscale fsdp cpu offloading py for more detail see example variant prediction for code and pre trained weight for the esm v model described in language model enable zero shot prediction of the effect of mutation on protein function meier et al note that esm could be used for variant prediction a well and is expected to have similar performance to esm v see example inverse folding for detailed user guide the esm if model is described a gvptransformer in learning inverse folding from million of predicted structure hsu et al we also provide a colab notebook for the sequence design and sequence scoring functionality the esm if inverse folding model is built for predicting protein sequence from their backbone atom coordinate we provide script here to sample sequence design for a given structure and to score sequence for a given structure trained with m protein structure predicted by alphafold the esm if model consists of invariant geometric input processing layer followed by a sequence to sequence transformer and achieves native sequence recovery on structurally held out backbone with recovery for buried residue the model is also trained with span masking to tolerate missing backbone coordinate and therefore can predict sequence for partially masked structure the environment setup is described in this subsection of example inverse folding to sample sequence for a given structure in pdb or mmcif format use the sample sequence py script the input file can have either pdb or cif a suffix for example to sample sequence design for the golgi casein kinase structure pdb yh pdb molecule of the month from january we can run the following command from the esm root directory the sampled sequence will be saved in a fasta format to the specified output file the temperature parameter control the sharpness of the probability distribution for sequence sampling higher sampling temperature yield more diverse sequence but likely with lower native sequence recovery the default sampling temperature is to optimize for native sequence recovery we recommend sampling with low temperature such a e to score the conditional log likelihood for sequence conditioned on a given structure use the score log likelihood py script for example to score the sequence in example inverse folding data yh mutated seqs fasta according to the structure in example inverse folding data yh pdb we can run the following command from the esm root directory the conditional log likelihood are saved in a csv format in the specified output path the output value are the average log likelihood averaged over all amino acid in a sequence for more information see example inverse folding for detailed user guide the esm if inverse folding model predicts protein sequence from their backbone atom coordinate trained with m protein structure predicted by alphafold this notetook guide you through example of sampling sequence calculating conditional log likelihood and extracting encoder output a structure representation to help you get started with using the embeddings this jupyter notebook tutorial show how to train a supervised variant predictor using embeddings from esm you can adopt a similar protocol to train a model for any downstream task even with limited data first you can obtain the embeddings for example data p fasta either by downloading the precomputed embeddings a instructed in the notebook or by running the following then follow the remaining instruction in the tutorial you can also run the tutorial in a colab notebook note alternatively use the newer instruction for zero shot variant prediction which predicts mutational effect without any supervised training this jupyter notebook tutorial demonstrates contact prediction with both the esm and msa transformer esm msa model contact prediction is based on a logistic regression over the model s attention map this methodology is based on our iclr paper transformer protein language model are unsupervised structure learner rao et al the msa transformer esm msa take a multiple sequence alignment msa a input and us the tied row self attention map in the same way see msa transformer rao et al to get unsupervised attention based contact call model predict contact token or model token return contact true and this jupyter notebook tutorial show how to load and index the esmstructuralsplitdataset and computes the self attention map unsupervised contact prediction using esm here is a chronological list of the released model and the paper they were introduced in this is a five fold cross validation dataset of protein domain structure that can be used to measure generalization of representation across different level of structural dissimilarity the dataset implement structural holdout at the family superfamily and fold level the scope database is used to classify domain independently for each level of structural hold out the domain are split into equal set i e five set of fold superfamily or family this ensures that for each of the five partition structure having the same classification do not appear in both the train and test set for a given classification level each structure appears in a test set once so that in the cross validation experiment each of the structure will be evaluated exactly once the dataset provides d coordinate distance map and secondary structure label for further detail on the construction of the dataset see rives et al appendix a this jupyter notebook tutorial show how to load and index the esmstructuralsplitdataset esmstructuralsplitdataset upon initializing will download split and pkl we also provide msas for each of the domain the data can be directly downloaded below the split file establishing which uniref cluster were used a held out evaluation set for pre training in rives et al and rao et al can be found here these file only contain only the uniref id and uniref id corresponding to the uniref database release which is released by the uniprot consortium under a creative common attribution cc by license if you find the model useful in your research we ask that you cite the relevant paper for the self attention contact prediction for the msa transformer for variant prediction using esm v for inverse folding using esm if for the esm language model and esmfold much of this code build on the fairseq sequence modeling framework we use fairseq internally for our protein language modeling research we highly recommend trying it out if you d like to pre train protein language model from scratch additionally if you would like to use the variant prediction benchmark from meier et al we provide a bibtex file with citation for all data in example variant prediction mutation data bib you can cite each paper individually or add all citation in bulk using the latex command this source code is licensed under the mit license found in the license file in the root directory of this source tree

description: aboutmetaphonedouble metaphonehistoryusagerunning the unit testsexample codein the wilda python implementation of the metaphone and double metaphone algorithmsas described on the wikipedia page the original metaphone algorithm wa published in a an improvement over the soundex algorithm like soundex it wa limited to english only use the metaphone algorithm doe not produce phonetic representation of an input word or name rather the output is an intentionally approximate phonetic representation the approximate encoding is necessary to account for the way speaker vary their pronunciation and misspell or otherwise vary word and name they are trying to spell the double metaphone phonetic encoding algorithm is the second generation of the metaphone algorithm it implementation wa described in the june issue of c c user journal it make a number of fundamental design improvement over the original metaphone algorithm it is called double because it can return both a primary and a secondary code for a string this account for some ambiguous case a well a for multiple variant of surname with common ancestry for example encoding the name smith yield a primary code of sm and a secondary code of xmt while the name schmidt yield a primary code of xmt and a secondary code of smt both have xmt in common double metaphone try to account for myriad irregularity in english of slavic germanic celtic greek french italian spanish chinese and other origin thus it us a much more complex ruleset for coding than it predecessor for example it test for approximately different context of the use of the letter c alone this is a copy of the python double metaphone algorithm taken from andrew collins work a python implementation of an algorithm in c originally created by lawrence philip since then improvement have been made by several contributor viewable in the git history a resource directory is included with this project which contains the following the original c file by lawrence philipskevin atkinson s improvement to ita c implementation for use in a perl extension by maurice aubreythe contributor of the python version originally started by andrew collins include andrew collinschris leongmatthew somervillerichard barranmaximillian dornseifsebastien metrotduncan mcgreggorollie bennettian beaveralastair houghtonmetaphone us the unittest package from the standard library and a such it test are runnable by most test runner if you have nose installed you can do the following if you have twisted installed you can do the unit test are full of example so be sure to check those out but here s a taste the following developer project make use of this library andrew collins used his original code in various music project and dealing with misspelled text from data provided by various web service this wa then integrated with plone zope project matthew somerville us it on theatricalia to do people name matching and it appears to work quite well the database store the double metaphones for first and last name and then upon searching simply computes the double metaphones of what ha been entered and look up anything that match duncan mcgreggor us it on the arsk project to provide greater full text search capability for indo european language word list and dictionary

description: at least for the people who send me mail about a new language that they re designing the general advice is do it to learn about how to write a compiler don t have any expectation that anyone will use it unless you hook up with some sort of organization in a position to push it hard it s a lottery and some can buy a lot of the ticket there are plenty of beautiful language more beautiful than c that didn t catch on but someone doe win the lottery and doing a language at least teach you something dennis ritchie creator of the c programming language and of unix tatsu is a tool that take grammar in a variation of ebnf a input and output memoizing packrat peg parser in python why use a peg parser because regular language those parsable with python s re package cannot count any language with nested structure or with balancing of demarcation requires more than regular expression to be parsed tatsu can compile a grammar stored in a string into a tatsu grammar grammar object that can be used to parse any given input much like the re module doe with regular expression or it can generate a python module that implement the parser tatsu support left recursive rule in peg grammar using the algorithm by laurent and men the generated ast ha the expected left associativity starting with version tatsu requires python or later while no code in tatsu yet depends on new language or standard library feature the author don t want to be constrained by python version comaptibility consideration when developing feature that will be part future release therefore to simplify version pinning for user of the library they decided to proactively bump the python minimum required version to tatsu release in the series closely track release in the series while maintaining compatibility with python and later bug fix are back ported from release feature are back ported from the release unless they depend on python feature not available on the supported python version refer to the changelog for detail tatsu can be used a a library much like python s re by embedding grammar a string and generating grammar model instead of generating python code tatsu compile grammar name none kwargs compiles the grammar and generates a model that can subsequently be used for parsing input with tatsu parse grammar input kwargs compiles the grammar and par the given input producing an ast a result the result is equivalent to calling compiled grammar are cached for efficiency tatsu to python sourcecode grammar name none filename none kwargs compiles the grammar to the python sourcecode that implement the parser this is an example of how to use tatsu a a library tatsu will use the first rule defined in the grammar a the start rule this is the output for a detailed explanation of what tatsu is capable of please see the documentation please use the tatsu tag on stackoverflow for general q a and limit github issue to bug enhancement proposal and feature request see the changelog for detail you may use tatsu under the term of the bsd style license described in the enclosed license txt file if your project requires different licensing please email

description: an mt based sentence alignment toolcopyright rico sennrich sennrich cl uzh ch a project of the computational linguistics group at the university of zurich http www cl uzh ch project homepage http github com rsennrich bleualignthis program is free software you can redistribute it and or modify it under the term of the gnu general public license a published by the free software foundationbleualign is a tool to align parallel text i e a text and it translation on a sentence level additionally to the source and target text bleualign requires an automatic translation of at least one of the text the alignment is then performed on the basis of the similarity modified bleu score between the source text sentence translated into the target language and the target text sentence see section publication for more detail obtaining an automatic translation is up to the user the only requirement is that the translation must correspond line by line to the source text no line break inserted or removed the software wa developed on linux using python but should also support newer version of python including x and other platform please report any issue you encounter to sennrich cl uzh chthe input and output format of bleualign are one sentence per line a line which only contains eoa is considered a hard delimiter end of article sentence alignment doe not cross these delimiters reliable delimiters improve speed and performance wrong one will seriously degrade performance given the file sourcetext txt targettext txt and sourcetranslation txt the latter being sentence aligned with sourcetext txt a sample call is bleualign py s sourcetext txt t targettext txt srctotarget sourcetranslation txt o outputfileit is also possible to provide several translation and or translation in the other translation direction bleualign will run once per translation provided the final output being the intersection of the individual run i e sentence pair produced in each individual run bleualign py s sourcetext txt t targettext txt srctotarget sourcetranslation txt srctotarget sourcetranslation txt targettosrc targettranslation txt o outputfile bleualign py h will show more usage optionsto facilitate batch processing multiple file batch align py can be used python batch align directory source suffix target suffix translation suffixexample given the directory raw file with the file de fr and trans and so on trans being the translation of de into the target language then this command will align all file python batch align py raw file de fr transthis will produce the file de aligned and fr alignedbleualign work a stand alone script but can also be imported a a module other python project for code example see the example directory if you want to know all option you can see aligner default option variable in bleualign aligner py to use bleualign a a python module the package need to be installed from a local copy with python setup py installthe bleualign package can also be installed directly from github with pip install git http github com rsennrich bleualign gitthe algorithm is described inmt based sentence alignment for ocr generated parallel text in proceeding of amta denver colorado iterative mt based sentence alignment of parallel text in nodalida nordic conference of computational linguistics riga for question and feeback please contact sennrich cl uzh ch or use the github repository

description: markovify is a simple extensible markov chain generator right now it primary use is for building markov model of large corpus of text and generating random sentence from that however in theory it could be used for other application some reason simplicity battery included but it is easy to override key method model can be stored a json allowing you to cache your result and save them for later text parsing and sentence generation method are highly extensible allowing you to set your own rule relies only on pure python library and very few of them tested on python and note the usage example here assume you are trying to markovify text if you would like to use the underlying markovify chain class which is not text specific check out the annotated source code markovify work best with large well punctuated text if your text doe not use s to delineate sentence put each sentence on a newline and use the markovify newlinetext class instead of markovify text class if you have accidentally read the input text a one long sentence markovify will be unable to generate new sentence from it due to a lack of beginning and ending delimiters this issue can occur if you have read a newline delimited file using the markovify text command instead of markovify newlinetext to check this the command key for key in txt chain model key if begin in key command will return all of the possible sentence starting word and should return more than one result by default the make sentence method try a maximum of time per invocation to make a sentence that doe not overlap too much with the original text if it is successful the method return the sentence a a string if not it return none to increase or decrease the number of attempt use the try keyword argument e g call make sentence try by default markovify text try to generate sentence that do not simply regurgitate chunk of the original text the default rule is to suppress any generated sentence that exactly overlap the original text by word or of the sentence s word count you can change this rule by passing max overlap ratio and or max overlap total to the make sentence method alternatively this check can be disabled entirely by passing test output a false state size is a number of word the probability of a next word depends on by default markovify text us a state size of but you can instantiate a model with a different state size e g with markovify combine you can combine two or more markov chain the function accepts two argument for instance this code snippet would combine model a and model b but it would also place more weight on the connection from model a once a model ha been generated it may also be compiled for improved text generation speed and reduced size model may also be compiled in place currently compiled model may not be combined with other model using markovify combine if you wish to combine model do that first and then compile the result starting with v markovify text accepts two additional parameter well formed and reject reg setting well formed false skip the step in which input sentence are rejected if they contain one of the bad character i e setting reject reg to a regular expression of your choice allows you change the input sentence rejection pattern this only applies if well formed is true and if the expression is non empty the markovify text class is highly extensible most method can be overridden for example the following posifiedtext class us nltk s part of speech tagger to generate a markov model that obeys sentence structure better than a naive model it work however be warned po tag is very slow or you can use spacy which is way faster the most useful markovify text model you can override are for detail on what they do see the annotated source code it can take a while to generate a markov model from a large corpus sometimes you ll want to generate once and reuse it later to export a generated markovify text model use my text model to json for example you can also export the underlying markov chain on it own i e excluding the original corpus and the state size metadata via my text model chain to json by default the markovify text class load and retains your textual corpus so that it can compare generated sentence with the original and only emit novel sentence however with very large corpus loading the entire text at once and retaining it can be memory intensive to overcome this you can a tell markovify not to retain the original and b read in the corpus line by line or file by file and combine them into one model at each step have other example pull request welcome many thanks to the following github user for contributing code and or idea initially developed at buzzfeed

description: descriptionwhat can it do documentationrequirementsinstallationuninstallationdemonice to implement in the futurecontributingauthorslicensethis is a python library and command line tool that help you search for a word or a phrase within an audio file wav format it also builts upon the initial searching capability and provides some so called advanced searching ability index audio file using watson online higher quality or cmu pocketsphinx offline lower quality and save load the result searching within audio file in multiple language default is english define a timing error for your query to handle discrepencies define constraint on your query e g whether to include sub super sequence result with missing word etc do full blown regex pattern matching to read the documentation visit here python v or with pip installed watson api credential and or cmu pocketsphinxsoxffmpeg if you choose cmu pocketsphinx py text and tox if you want to run the test open up a terminal and enter installation detail can be found at the documentation here there s a dockerfile included withing the repo if you re unable to do a native installation or are on a window system open up a terminal and enter uninstalling sox however is dependent upon whether you re on a linux or mac system for more information visit here say you have this audio file have it downloaded to an empty directory for simplicity we d refer to that directory a src dir and the name of this audio file a small audio wav here s how you can search through it open up a terminal and enter replace username and password with your ibm watson s credential and src dir with the absolute path to the directory you just prepared the out would be like above a dictionary that ha the query the file s it appears in and the all of the starting second ending second of that query note that all command work uniformally for other engine i e pocketsphinx for example the command above can be enterred a which would use pocketsphinx instead of watson to get the timestamps note that the quality accuracy of pocketsphinx is much lower than watson instead of searching for a word you could also match a regex pattern for example that wa the result of searching for two letter word note that your result would match any aribtrary regular expression you may also save and load the indexed data from the command line script for more information visit here say you have this fileafterwards you should create an instance of sainow you may index all the available audio file by calling index audio method you could have a searching generator now there are quite a few more argument implemented for search gen say you wanted your search to be case sensitive by default it s not or say you wanted to look for a phrase but there s a timing gap and the indexer didn t pick it up right you could specify timing error or say some word is completely missed then you could specify missing word tolerance etc for a full list see the api reference herenote that you could also call search all method to have search for a list of query within all the audio file finally you could do a regex search there are more functionality implemented for detailed explainations read the documentation here uploading in parallelmore control structure for searching typo phoneme based approximation of word using cmu dict or nltk etc searching for an unintelligible audio within the audio file possibly by cross correlation or something similar should you want to contribute code or idea file a bug request or give feedback visit the contributing file alireza rafiei aalirezasee also the list of contributor to this project this project is licensed under the apache v license see the licence file for more detail

description: warning pyfasttext is no longer maintained use the official python binding from the fasttext repository http github com facebookresearch fasttext tree master pythonyet another python binding for fasttext the binding support python and python it requires cython numpy and cysignals are also dependency but are optional pyfasttexttable of contentsinstallationsimplest way to install pyfasttext use pippossible compilation errorcloningrequirements for python building and installing manuallybuilding and installing without optional dependenciesusagehow to load the library how to load an existing model word representation learningtraining using skipgramtraining using cbowword vectorsword vector accessvector for a given wordnumpy ndarraywords for a given vectorget the number of word in the modelget all the word vector in a modelnumpy ndarraymisc operation with word vectorsword similaritymost similar wordsanalogiestext classificationsupervised learningget all the labelsget the number of labelspredictionlabels and probabilitiesnormalized probabilitieslabels onlyquantizationis a model quantized subwordsget the subwordsget the subword vectorssentence and text vectorsunsupervised modelssupervised modelsmisc utilitiesshow the module versionshow fasttext versionshow the model hyper parametersshow the model version numberextract label or class from a datasetextract labelsextract classesexceptionsinterruptible operationsto compile pyfasttext make sure you have the following compiler gcc g with c support llvm clang with at least partial c support just type these line if you have a compilation error you can try to install cysignals manually then retry to install pyfasttext with the already mentioned pip command first install all the requirement then build and install with setup py pyfasttext can export word vector a numpy ndarrays however this feature can be disabled at compile time to compile without numpy pyfasttext ha a use numpy environment variable set this variable to or empty like this if you want to compile without cysignals likewise you can set the use cysignals environment variable to or empty orby default a single word vector is returned a a regular python array of float numpy ndarraythe model get numpy vector word method return the word vector a a numpy ndarray if you want a normalized vector i e the vector divided by it norm there is an optional boolean parameter named normalized numpy ndarrayif you want all the word vector a a big numpy ndarray you can use the numpy normalized vector member note that all these vector are normalized the model most similar method work similarly a the one in gensim if you have a list of string or an iterable object use this if you want to test a single string use this warning in order to get the same probability a the fasttext binary you have to add a newline n at the end of each string if your test data is stored inside a file use this normalized probabilitiesfor performance reason fasttext probability often do not sum up to if you want normalized probability where the sum is closer to than the original probability you can use the normalized true parameter in all the method that output probability model predict proba model predict proba file and model predict proba single if you have a list of string or an iterable object use this if you want to test a single string use this warning in order to get the same probability a the fasttext binary you have to add a newline n at the end of each string if your test data is stored inside a file use this use keyword argument in the model quantize method you can load quantized model using the fasttext constructor or the model load model method if you want to know if a model ha been quantized before use the model quantized attribute fasttext can use subwords i e character ngrams when doing unsupervised or supervised learning you can access the subwords and their associated vector using pyfasttext fasttext s word embeddings can be augmented with subword level information it is possible to retrieve the subwords and their associated vector from a model using pyfasttext to retrieve all the subwords for a given word use the model get all subwords word method for fasttext mean beginning of a word and mean end of a word a you can see fasttext includes the full word you can omit it using the omit word true keyword argument when a model is quantized fasttext may prune some subwords if you want to see only the subwords that are really used when computing a word vector you should use the model get subwords word method to get the individual vector given the subwords use the model get numpy subword vector word method in fasttext the final word vector is the average of these individual vector to compute the vector of a sequence of word i e a sentence fasttext us two different method one for unsupervised model another one for supervised modelswhen fasttext computes a word vector recall that it us the average of the following vector the word itself and it subwords for unsupervised model the representation of a sentence for fasttext is the average of the normalized word vector for supervised model fasttext us the regular word vector a well a vector computed using word ngrams i e shorter sequence of word from the sentence when computing the average these vector are not normalized a there is no version number in fasttext we use the latest fasttext commit hash from head a a substitute fasttext us a versioning scheme for it generated model you can retrieve the model version number using the model version attribute version numberdescription for really old model with no version number first version number added by fasttext for model generated after fasttext added support for subwords in supervised learningyou can use the fasttext object to extract label or class from a dataset the label prefix which is label by default is set using the label parameter in the constructor if you load an existing model the label prefix will be the one defined in the model there can be multiple label per line there can be only one class per line the fasttext source code directly call exit when something wrong happens e g a model file doe not exist instead of exiting pyfasttext raise a python exception runtimeerror pyfasttext us cysignals to make all the computationally intensive operation e g training interruptible to easily interrupt such an operation just type ctrl c in your python shell

description: bi directional transliterator for python transliterates unicode string according to the rule specified in the language pack source script target script come with language pack for the following language listed in alphabetical order armenianbulgarian beta georgiangreekmacedonian alpha mongolian alpha russianserbian alpha ukrainian beta there are also a number of useful tool included such a simple lorem ipsum generator which allows lorem ipsum generation in the language chosen language detection for the text if appropriate language pack is available slugify function for non latin text python pypyinstall with latest stable version from pypi or install the latest stable version from bitbucket or install the latest stable version from github that s all see the usage and example section for more required importsoriginal texttransliteration to armeniantransliteration to georgiantransliteration to greektransliteration to russianlist of available registered languagesreversed transliteration are transliteration made from target language to source language in term they are defined in language pack in case of reversed transliteration you may leave out the language code attribute although if you know it on beforehand specify it since it work faster that way reversed transliteration from armenianreversed transliteration from armenian with language code argument left outreversed transliteration from georgianreversed transliteration from georgian with language code argument left outreversed transliteration from greekreversed transliteration from greek with language code argument left outreversed transliteration from russian cyrillic reversed transliteration from russian cyrillic with language code argument left outtesting the decoratorif you know which language pack shall be used for transliteration especially when working with large amount of data it make sense to get the transliteration function in the following way make sure to call the autodiscover function before registering your own language pack if you want to use the bundled language pack along with your own custom one then the custom language pack part come it s possible to replace existing language pack with your own one by default existing language pack are not force installed to force install a language pack set the force argument to true when registering a language pack in that case if a language pack with same language code ha already been registered it will be replaced otherwise if language pack didn t exist in the registry it will be just registered forced language pack can t be replaced or unregistered there are class property that you could should be using in your language pack of which are various sort of mapping mapping tuple a tuple of two string that simply represent the mapping of character from the source language to the target language for example if your source language is latin and you want to convert a b c d and e character to appropriate character in russian cyrillic your mapping would look a follows example taken from the greek language pack reversed specific mapping tuple when making reversed translation the mapping property is still used but in some case you need to provide additional rule this property reversed specific mapping is meant for such case further is alike the mapping example taken from the greek language pack pre processor mapping dict a dictionary of mapping from source language to target language use this only in case if a single character in source language shall be represented by more than one character in the target language example taken from the greek language pack reversed specific pre processor mapping same a pre processor mapping but used in reversed translation example taken from the armenian language pack character range tuple a tuple of character range unicode table used in language detection work only if detectable property is set to true be aware that language or shall i better be saying script detection is very basic and is based on character only detectable bool if set to true language pack would be used for automatic language detection note that due to incompatibility of the original lorem ipsum generator package with python when used with python transliterate us it own simplified fallback lorem ipsum generator which still doe the job required importsgenerating paragraph in armeniangenerating sentense in georgiangenerating sentense in greekgenerating sentense in russian cyrillic required importsdetect armenian textdetect georgian textdetect greek textdetect russian cyrillic textrequired importsslugify armenian textslugify georgian textslugify greek textslugify russian cyrillic textmissing a language pack for your own language contribute to the project by making one and it will appear in a new version which will be released very quickly keep the following hierarchy gpl lgpl for any issue contact me at the e mail given in the author section artur barseghyan artur barseghyan gmail com

description: greynir is a python package published by mi eind ehf for working with icelandic natural language text greynir can parse text into sentence tree find lemma inflect noun phrase assign part of speech tag and much more greynir s sentence tree can inter alia be used to extract information from text for instance about people title entity fact action and opinion full documentation for greynir is available here greynir is the engine of greynir is a natural language front end for a database of over million sentence parsed from icelandic news article and embla a voice driven virtual assistant app for smart device such a io and android phone greynir includes a hand written context free grammar for the icelandic language consisting of over line of grammatical production in extended backus naur format it fast c parser core is able to cope with long and ambiguous sentence using an earley type parser a enhanced by scott and johnstone greynir employ the tokenizer package by the same author to tokenize text and us binpackage a it database of icelandic vocabulary and morphology the program output the following text correctly inflected this package run on cpython or newer and on pypy or newer to find out which version of python you have enter if a binary wheel package isn t available on pypi for your system you may need to have the python dev package or it window equivalent installed on your system to set up greynir successfully this is because a source distribution install requires a c compiler and linker depending on your system you may also need to install libffi dev to install this package assuming python is your default python if you have git installed and want to be able to edit the source do like so the package source code is now in greynirpackage src reynir description: icegrams is an mit licensed python package that encapsulates a large trigram library for icelandic a trigram is a tuple of three consecutive word or token that appear in real world text million unique trigram and their frequency count are heavily compressed using radix try and quasi succinct index employing elia fano encoding this enables the megabyte compressed trigram file to be mapped directly into memory with no ex ante decompression for fast query typically microsecond per lookup the icegrams library is implemented in python and c c glued together via cffi the trigram storage approach is based on a paper by pibiri and venturini also referring to ottaviano and venturini regarding partitioned elia fano index you can use icegrams to obtain probability relative frequency of over a million different unigrams single word or token or of bigram pair of two word or token or of trigram you can also ask it to return the n most likely successor to any unigram or bigram icegrams is useful for instance in spelling correction predictive typing to help disabled people write text faster and for various text generation statistic and modelling task the icegrams trigram corpus is built from the edition of the icelandic gigaword corpus risam lheild which is collected and maintained by the rni magn sson institute for icelandic study a mixed manually vetted subset consisting of document from the corpus wa used a the source of the token stream yielding over million token trigram that only occurred once or twice in the stream were eliminated before creating the compressed icegrams database the creation process is further described here after installing the icegrams package use the following code to import it and initialize an instance of the ngrams class now you can use the ng instance to query for unigram bigram and trigram frequency and probability init self initializes the ngrams instance freq self args intreturns the frequency of a unigram bigram or trigram str args a parameter sequence of consecutive unigrams to query the frequency for return an integer with the frequency of the unigram bigram or trigram to query for the frequency of a unigram in the text call ng freq unigram this return the number of time that the unigram appears in the database the unigram is queried a is i e with no string stripping or lowercasing to query for the frequency of a bigram in the text call ng freq unigram unigram to query for the frequency of a trigram in the text call ng freq unigram unigram unigram if you pas more than argument to ng freq only the last are significant and the query will be treated a a trigram query example adj freq self args intreturns the adjusted frequency of a unigram bigram or trigram str args a parameter sequence of consecutive unigrams to query the frequency for return an integer with the adjusted frequency of the unigram bigram or trigram the adjusted frequency is the actual frequency plus the method thus never return to query for the frequency of a unigram in the text call ng adj freq unigram this return the number of time that the unigram appears in the database plus the unigram is queried a is i e with no string stripping or lowercasing to query for the frequency of a bigram in the text call ng adj freq unigram unigram to query for the frequency of a trigram in the text call ng adj freq unigram unigram unigram if you pas more than argument to ng adj freq only the last are significant and the query will be treated a a trigram query example prob self args floatreturns the probability of a unigram bigram or trigram str args a parameter sequence of consecutive unigrams to query the probability for return a float with the probability of the given unigram bigram or trigram the probability of a unigram is the frequency of the unigram divided by the sum of the frequency of all unigrams in the database the probability of a bigram u u is the frequency of the bigram divided by the frequency of the unigram u i e how likely u is to succeed u the probability of a trigram u u u is the frequency of the trigram divided by the frequency of the bigram u u i e how likely u is to succeed u u if you pas more than argument to ng prob only the last are significant and the query will be treated a a trigram probability query example logprob self args floatreturns the log probability of a unigram bigram or trigram str args a parameter sequence of consecutive unigrams to query the log probability for return a float with the natural logarithm base e of the probability of the given unigram bigram or trigram the probability of a unigram is the adjusted frequency of the unigram divided by the sum of the frequency of all unigrams in the database the probability of a bigram u u is the adjusted frequency of the bigram divided by the adjusted frequency of the unigram u i e how likely u is to succeed u the probability of a trigram u u u is the adjusted frequency of the trigram divided by the adjusted frequency of the bigram u u i e how likely u is to succeed u u if you pas more than argument to ng logprob only the last are significant and the query will be treated a a trigram probability query example succ self n args list tuple return the n most probable successor of a unigram or bigram int n a positive integer specifying how many successor at a maximum should be returned str args one or two string parameter containing the unigram or bigram to query the successor for return a list of tuples of successor unigram log probability in descending order of probability if you pas more than string argument to ng succ only the last are significant and the query will be treated a a bigram successor query example icegrams is built with a sliding window over the source text this mean that a sentence such a ma urinn bor a i sinn result in the following trigram being added to the database the same sliding window strategy is applied for bigram so the following bigram would be recorded for the same sentence you can thus obtain the n unigrams that most often start a sentence by asking for ng succ n and of course four unigrams are also added one for each token in the sentence the tokenization of the source text into unigrams is done with the tokenizer package and us the rule documented there importantly token other than word abbreviation entity name person name and punctuation are replaced by placeholder this mean that all number are represented by the token number amount by amount date by dateabs and daterel e mail address by email etc for the complete mapping of token type to placeholder string see the documentation for the tokenizer package this package run on cpython or newer and on pypy or newer it ha been tested on linux gcc on x and armhf macos clang and window msvc if a binary wheel package isn t available on pypi for your system you may need to have the python dev package or it window equivalent installed on your system to set up icegrams successfully this is because a source distribution install requires a c compiler and linker to install this package if you want to be able to edit the source do like so assuming you have git installed the package source code is now in src icegrams to run the built in test install pytest cd to your icegrams subdirectory and optionally activate your virtualenv then run version python support dropped macos build fixed pypy wheel generatedversion new trigram database sourced from the icelandic gigaword corpus risam lheild with improved tokenization replaced gnu gplv with mit license version python type annotation addedversion trigram corpus ha been spell checked

description: rake short for rapid automatic keyword extraction algorithm is a domain independent keyword extraction algorithm which try to determine key phrase in a body of text by analyzing the frequency of word appearance and it co occurance with other word in the text ridiculously simple interface configurable word and sentence tokenizers language based stop word etcconfigurable ranking metric if you see a stopwords error it mean that you do not have the corpus stopwords downloaded from nltk you can download it using command below this is a python implementation of the algorithm a mentioned in paper automatic keyword extraction from individual document by stuart rose dave engel nick cramer and wendy cowleyit is extremely fun to implement algorithm by reading paper it is the digital equivalent of diy kit there are some rather popular implementation out there in python aneesha rake and node waseem node rake but neither seemed to use the power of nltk by making nltk an integral part of the implementation i get the flexibility and power to extend it in other creative way if i see fit later without having to implement everything myself i plan to use it in my other pet project to come and wanted it to be modular and tunable and this way i have complete control please use issue tracker for reporting bug or feature request checkout the repository make your change and add update relavent test install poetry using pip install poetry run poetry install to create project s virtual environment run test using poetry run tox any python version which you don t have commit the change and raise a pull request if you found the utility helpful you can buy me a cup of coffee using

description: wordfreq is a python library for looking up the frequency of word in many language based on many source of data author robyn speerwordfreq requires python and depends on a few other python module msgpack langcodes and regex you can install it and it dependency in the usual way either by getting it from pip or by getting the repository and installing it for development using poetry see additional cjk installation for extra step that are necessary to get chinese japanese and korean word frequency wordfreq provides access to estimate of the frequency with which a word is used in over language see supported language below it us many different data source not just one corpus it provides both small and large wordlists the default list is best which us large if it s available for the language and small otherwise the most straightforward function for looking up frequency is this function look up a word s frequency in the given language returning it frequency a a decimal between and zipf frequency is a variation on word frequency that aim to return the word frequency on a human friendly logarithmic scale the zipf scale wa proposed by marc brysbaert who created the subtlex list the zipf frequency of a word is the base logarithm of the number of time it appears per billion word a word with zipf value appears once per thousand word for example and a word with zipf value appears once per million word reasonable zipf value are between and but because of the cutoff described above the minimum zipf value appearing in these list is for the large wordlists and for small we use a the default zipf value for word that do not appear in the given wordlist although it should mean one occurrence per billion word the parameter to word frequency and zipf frequency are word a unicode string containing the word to look up ideally the word is a single token according to our tokenizer but if not there is still hope see tokenization below lang the bcp or iso code of the language to use such a en wordlist which set of word frequency to use current option are small large and best minimum if the word is not in the list or ha a frequency lower than minimum return minimum instead you may want to set this to the minimum value contained in the wordlist to avoid a discontinuity where the wordlist end wordfreq s wordlists are designed to load quickly and take up little space in the repository we accomplish this by avoiding meaningless precision and packing the word into frequency bin in wordfreq all word that have the same zipf frequency rounded to the nearest hundredth have the same frequency we don t store any more precision than that so instead of having to store that the frequency of a word is where most of those digit are meaningless we just store the frequency bin and the word they contain because the zipf scale is a logarithmic scale this preserve the same relative precision no matter how far down you are in the word list the frequency of any word is precise to within this is not a claim about accuracy but about precision we believe that the way we use multiple data source and discard outlier make wordfreq a more accurate measurement of the way these word are really used in written language but it s unclear how one would measure this accuracy we combine word frequency from different source in a way that s designed to minimize the impact of outlier the method reminds me of the scoring system in olympic figure skating these wordlists would be enormous if they stored a separate frequency for every number such a if we separately stored the frequency of and and and every other character sequence that could be considered a number instead we have a frequency bin entry for every number of the same shape such a or or with standing in for digit for compatibility with earlier version of wordfreq our stand in character is actually this is the same form of aggregation that the word vec vocabulary doe single digit number are unaffected by this process through have their own entry in each language s wordlist when asked for the frequency of a token containing multiple digit we multiply the frequency of that aggregated entry by a distribution estimating the frequency of those digit the distribution only look at two thing the first digit are assigned probability by benford s law and year are assigned probability from a distribution that peak at the present i explored this in a twitter thread at http twitter com r speer status the part of this distribution representing the present is not strictly a peak and doesn t move forward with time a the present doe instead it s a year long plateau from to is the last time google book ngrams wa updated and is a time by which i will probably have figured out a new distribution some example aside from year the distribution doe not care about the meaning of the number the digit rule applies to other system of digit and only care about the numeric value of the digit it doesn t know which language us which writing system for digit this data come from a luminoso project called exquisite corpus whose goal is to download good varied multilingual corpus data process it appropriately and combine it into unified resource such a wordfreq exquisite corpus compiles different domain of text some of which themselves come from multiple source the following language are supported with reasonable tokenization and at least different source of word frequency bosnian croatian and serbian use the same underlying word list because they share most of their vocabulary and grammar they were once considered the same language and language detection cannot distinguish them this word list can also be accessed with the language code sh the norwegian text we have is specifically written in norwegian bokm l so we give it the language code nb instead of the vaguer code no we would use nn for nynorsk but there isn t enough data to include it in wordfreq this data represents text written in both simplified and traditional chinese with primarily mandarin chinese vocabulary see multi script language below some language provide large wordlists including word with a zipf frequency between and these are available in language that are covered by enough data source tokenize text lang split text in the given language into word in the same way that the word in wordfreq s data were counted in the first place see tokenization top n list lang n wordlist best return the most common n word in the list in descending frequency order iter wordlist lang wordlist best iterates through all the word in a wordlist in descending frequency order get frequency dict lang wordlist best return all the frequency in a wordlist a a dictionary for case where you ll want to look up a lot of word and don t need the wrapper that word frequency provides available language wordlist best return a dictionary whose key are language code and whose value are the data file that will be loaded to provide the requested wordlist in each language get language info lang return a dictionary of information about how we preprocess text in this language such a what script we expect it to be written in which character we normalize together and how we tokenize it see it docstring for more information random word lang en wordlist best nwords bit per word return a selection of random word separated by space bit per word n will select each random word from n word if you happen to want an easy way to get a memorable xkcd style password with bit of entropy this function will almost do the job in this case you should actually run the similar function random ascii word limiting the selection to word that can be typed in ascii but maybe you should just use xkpa wordfreq us the python package regex which is a more advanced implementation of regular expression than the standard library to separate text into token that can be counted consistently regex produce token that follow the recommendation in unicode annex text segmentation including the optional rule that split word between apostrophe and vowel there are exception where we change the tokenization to work better with certain language in arabic and hebrew it additionally normalizes ligature and remove combining mark in japanese and korean instead of using the regex library it us the external library mecab python this is an optional dependency of wordfreq and compiling it requires the libmecab dev system package to be installed in chinese it us the external python library jieba another optional dependency while the sign is usually considered a symbol and not part of a word wordfreq will allow a word to end with or s this is one way of writing gender neutral word in spanish and portuguese when wordfreq s frequency list are built in the first place the word are tokenized according to this function because tokenization in the real world is far from consistent wordfreq will also try to deal gracefully when you query it with text that actually break into multiple token the word frequency are combined with the half harmonic mean function in order to provide an estimate of what their combined frequency would be in chinese where the word break must be inferred from the frequency of the resulting word there is also a penalty to the word frequency for each word break that must be inferred this method of combining word frequency implicitly assumes that you re asking about word that frequently appear together it s not multiplying the frequency because that would assume they are statistically unrelated so if you give it an uncommon combination of token it will hugely over estimate their frequency two of the language we support serbian and chinese are written in multiple script to avoid spurious difference in word frequency we automatically transliterate the character in these language when looking up their word serbian text written in cyrillic letter is automatically converted to latin letter using standard serbian transliteration when the requested language is sr or sh if you request the word list a hr croatian or b bosnian no transliteration will occur chinese text is converted internally to a representation we call oversimplified chinese where all traditional chinese character are replaced with their simplified chinese equivalent even if they would not be written that way in context this representation let u use a straightforward mapping that match both traditional and simplified word unifying their frequency when appropriate and doe not appear to create clash between unrelated word enumerating the chinese wordlist will produce some unfamiliar word because people don t actually write in oversimplified chinese and because in practice traditional and simplified chinese also have different word usage a much a we would like to give each language it own distinct code and it own distinct word list with distinct source data there aren t actually sharp boundary between language sometimes it s convenient to pretend that the boundary between language coincide with national border following the maxim that a language is a dialect with an army and a navy max weinreich this get complicated when the linguistic situation and the political situation diverge moreover some of our data source rely on language detection which of course ha no idea which country the writer of the text belongs to so we ve had to make some arbitrary decision about how to represent the fuzzier language boundary such a those within chinese malay and croatian bosnian serbian smoothing over our arbitrary decision is the fact that we use the langcodes module to find the best match for a language code if you ask for word frequency in cmn han the fully specific language code for mandarin in simplified chinese you will get the zh wordlist for example chinese japanese and korean have additional external dependency so that they can be tokenized correctly they can all be installed at once by requesting the cjk feature you can put wordfreq cjk in a list of dependency such a the tool poetry dependency list of your own project tokenizing chinese depends on the jieba package tokenizing japanese depends on mecab python and ipadic and tokenizing korean depends on mecab python and mecab ko dic a of version you no longer have to install dictionary separately wordfreq is freely redistributable under the apache license see license txt and it includes data file that may be redistributed under a creative common attribution sharealike license http creativecommons org license by sa wordfreq contains data extracted from google book ngrams http book google com ngrams and google book syntactic ngrams http commondatastorage googleapis com book syntactic ngrams index html the term of use of this data are wordfreq also contains data derived from the following creative common licensed source the leeds internet corpus from the university of leeds centre for translation study http corpus leeds ac uk list html wikipedia the free encyclopedia http www wikipedia org paracrawl a multilingual web crawl http paracrawl eu it contains data from opus opensubtitles http opus nlpl eu opensubtitles php whose data originates from the opensubtitles project http www opensubtitles org and may be used with attribution to opensubtitles it contains data from various subtlex word list subtlex u subtlex uk subtlex ch subtlex de and subtlex nl created by marc brysbaert et al see citation below and available at http crr ugent be program data subtitle frequency i robyn speer have obtained permission by e mail from marc brysbaert to distribute these wordlists in wordfreq to be used for any purpose not just for academic use under these condition these term are similar to the creative common attribution sharealike license some additional data wa collected by a custom application that watch the streaming twitter api in accordance with twitter s developer agreement policy this software give statistic about word that are commonly used on twitter it doe not display or republish any twitter content if you use wordfreq in your research please cite it we publish the code through zenodo so that it can be reliably cited using a doi the current citation is robyn speer rspeer wordfreq v v zenodo http doi org zenodo the same citation in bibtex format bojar o chatterjee r federmann c haddow b huck m hokamp c koehn p logacheva v monz c negri m post m scarton c specia l turchi m finding of the workshop on statistical machine translation description: a k a segtok v the syntok package provides two module syntok segmenter and syntok tokenizer the tokenizer provides functionality for splitting indo european text into word and symbol collectively called token the segmenter provides functionality for splitting indo european token stream from the tokenizer into sentence and for pre processing document by splitting them into paragraph both module can also be used from the command line to split either a given text file argument or by reading from stdin while other indo european language could work it ha only been designed with the language spanish english and german in mind the author s main language syntok is the successor of an earlier very similar tool segtok but ha evolved significantly in term of providing better segmentation and tokenization performance and throughput syntok can segment document at a rate of about k token per second without problem for example if a sentence terminal marker is not followed by a spacing character segtok is unable to detect that a a terminal marker while syntok ha no problem segmenting that case a it us tokenization first and doe segmentation afterwards in fact i feel confident enough to just boldly claim syntok is the world s best sentence segmenter for at least english spanish and german to use this package you minimally should have python or installed a it us the typing package earlier version are not supported the easiest way to get syntok installed is using pip or any other package manager that work with pypi important if you are on linux and have problem installing the regex dependency of syntok make sure you have the python dev and or python dev package installed to get the necessary header to compile that package then try the command line tool on some plain text file e g this readme to see if syntok meet your need syntok us poetry a the build tool and expects pyenv to provide the python version to test with tox therefore to develop syntok it is recommended that you install poetry and pyenv first install the python version defined in tox ini see envlist with pyenv and set all of them a your local version for example pyenv local to run the full test suite you have to install flake pytest and mypy via poetry install the test in the proper python version environment are run via tox or by calling the three command by hand for detail please refer to the code documentation this readme only provides an overview of the provided functionality after installing the package two command line usage will be available python m syntok segmenter and python m syntok tokenizer each take utf encoded plain text file or stdin until eof ctrl d a input and transforms that into newline separated sentence or space separated token respectively you can control python s file open encoding by configuring the environment variable pythonioencoding to your need e g export pythonioencoding utf be the tokenizer produce single space separated token for each input line the segmenter produce line segmented sentence for each input file or after stdin close this module provides the tokenizer class to tokenize input text into word and symbol value token prefixed with possibly empty spacing string while recording their offset position the tokenizer come with utility static function to join hyphenated word across line break and to reproduce the original string from a sequence of token the tokenizer considers camelcase word a individual token here camel and case and by default considers underscore and unicode hyphen inside word a spacing character not token value it doe not split numeric token without letter if they contain symbol e g maintaining or all a single token finally a it split english negation contraction such a don t into their root and not here do and not it can be configured to refrain from replacing this special n t token with not and instead emit the actual n t value to track the spacing and offset of token the module contains the token class which is a str wrapper class where the token value itself is available from the value property and adding a spacing and a offset property that will hold the spacing prefix and the offset position of the token respectively basic example this module provides several function to segment document into iterators over paragraph sentence and token function analyze and process or simply sentence and token function split and segment the analytic segmenter can even keep track of the original offset of each token in the document while processing but doe not join hyphen separated word across line break all segmenter function accept arbitrary token stream a input typically a generated by the tokenizer tokenize method due to how syntok tokenizer token object work it is possible to establish the exact sentence content with the original spacing between the token the pre processing function and paragraph based segmentation split paragraph i e chunk of text separated by at least two consecutive linebreaks r n basic example license mitcopyright c florian leitner all right reserved arjen p de vries arjenpdevries http www c ru nl arjen bastian zimmermann bastianzimp ter l ng peter lang dealogickoen dercksen kdercksen http koendercksen com sergiusz bleja svenskithank you bug fix support for single letter consontant abbreviation min and sen and german weekday abbreviation bug fix under splitting at month abbreviation and over splitting at no abbreviation improved handling of parenthesis at start of sentence and bugfix for citation at end of text support citation at sentence begin e g bible quote migrated to pyproject toml and tox ini dropped makefile build and py support splitting token around the zero width space characater u b bugfix for offset of not contraction discussion in issue segmenting now occurs at semi colon too discussion in issue bugfix for offset in multi nonword prefix token issue added a generic rule for catching more uncommon us of without space suffix a abbreviation marker added support for skipping and handling text in bracket e g citation fixed non trivial segmentation in sci text and refactored splitting logic to one place only added support for ellipsis back from segtok in hyphen joining only should happen when letter are present squash escape warning fixing segmenter analyze to preserve n t contraction and improved the readme and tokenizer constructor api initial release

description: googletrans is a free and unlimited python library that implemented google translate api this us the google translate ajax api to make call to such method a detect and translate compatible with python for detail refer to the api documentation fast and reliable it us the same server that translate google com usesauto language detectionbulk translationscustomizable service urlhttp supportmore feature are coming soon proxy supportinternal session management for better bulk translation this library us httpx for http request so http is supported by default you may wonder why this library work properly whereas other approach such like goslate won t work since google ha updated it translation service recently with a ticket mechanism to prevent a lot of crawler program i eventually figure out a way to generate a ticket by reverse engineering on the obfuscated and minified code used by google to generate such token and implemented on the top of python however this could be blocked at any time to install either use thing like pip with the package googletrans or download the package and put the googletrans directory into your python path if source language is not given google translate attempt to detect the source language you can use another google translate domain for translation if multiple url are provided it then randomly chooses a domain array can be used to translate a batch of string in a single method call and a single http session the exact same method shown above work for array a well the detect method a it name implies identifies the language used in a given sentence disclaimer this is an unofficial library using the web api of translate google com and also is not associated with google the maximum character limit on a single text is k due to limitation of the web version of google translate this api doe not guarantee that the library would work properly at all time so please use this library if you don t care about stability important if you want to use a stable api i highly recommend you to use google s official translate api if you get http xx error or error like it s probably because google ha banned your client ip address this library follows semantic versioning from v any release versioned x y is subject to backwards incompatible change at any time contribution to this library are always welcome and highly encouraged fork this project create a topic branch implement your feature or bug fix run pytest add a test for yout feature or bug fix run step again if your change are not covered go back to step
