description: textstat is an easy to use library to calculate statistic from text it help determine readability complexity and grade level photo by patrick tomasso on unsplash the argument text for all the defined function remains the same i e the text for which statistic need to be calculated you can install textstat either via the python package index pypi or from source download the latest version of textstat from http pypi python org pypi textstat you can install it by doing the following by default function implement algorithm for english language to change language use the language will be used for syllable calculation and to choose variant of the formula all function implement en u language some of them ha also variant for other language listed below the following function are specifically designed for spanish language they can be used on non spanish text even though that use case is not recommended additional information on the formula they implement can be found in their respective docstrings return the flesch reading ease score the following table can be helpful to ass the ease of readability in a document the table is an example of value while the maximum score is there is no limit on how low the score can be a negative score is valid further reading on wikipediareturns the flesch kincaid grade of the given text this is a grade formula in that a score of mean that a ninth grader would be able to read the document further reading on wikipediareturns the fog index of the given text this is a grade formula in that a score of mean that a ninth grader would be able to read the document further reading on wikipediareturns the smog index of the given text this is a grade formula in that a score of mean that a ninth grader would be able to read the document text of fewer than sentence are statistically invalid because the smog formula wa normed on sentence sample textstat requires at least sentence for a result further reading on wikipediareturns the ari automated readability index which output a number that approximates the grade level needed to comprehend the text for example if the ari is then the grade level to comprehend the text is th to th grade further reading on wikipediareturns the grade level of the text using the coleman liau formula this is a grade formula in that a score of mean that a ninth grader would be able to read the document further reading on wikipediareturns the grade level using the linsear write formula this is a grade formula in that a score of mean that a ninth grader would be able to read the document further reading on wikipediadifferent from other test since it us a lookup table of the most commonly used english word thus it return the grade level using the new dale chall formula further reading on wikipediabased upon all the above test return the estimated school grade level required to understand the text optional float output allows the score to be returned a a float default to false return grade level of english text intended for text written for child up to grade four further reading on wikipediareturns a score for the readability of an english text for a foreign learner or english focusing on the number of miniwords and length of sentence it is recommended to aim for a score equal to or lower than further reading on this blog postreturns the reading time of the given text assumes m per character further reading in this academic paperreformulation of the flesch reading ease formula specifically for spanish the result can be interpreted similarlyfurther reading on this blog postadaptation of flesch reading ease formula for spanish based text attempt to quantify how understandable a text is further reading on this blog postreturns the gutti rrez de polini understandability index specifically designed for the text in spanish not an adaptation conceived for grade school level text score for more complex text are not reliable further reading on this blog postreturns the crawford score for the text return an estimate of the year of schooling required to understand the text the text is only valid for elementary school level text further reading on this blog postreturns osman score for text designed for arabic an adaption of flesch and fog formula introduces a new factor called faseeh further reading in this academic paperreturns the gulpease index of italian text which translates to level of education completed lower score require higher level of education to read with ease further reading on wikipediareturns a grade level score for the given text a value of mean very easy text whereas mean very difficult text further reading on wikipediareturns the number of syllable present in the given text us the python module pyphen for syllable calculation calculates the number of word present in the text optional removepunct specifies whether we need to take punctuation symbol into account while counting lexicon default value is true which remove the punctuation before counting lexicon item return the number of sentence present in the given text return the number of character present in the given text return the number of character present in the given text without punctuation return the number of word with a syllable count greater than or equal to return the number of word with a syllable count equal to one if you find any problem you should open an issue if you can fix an issue you ve found or another issue you should open a pull request it is recommended you use a virtual environment or pipenv to keep your development work isolated from your system python installation

description: this is a tool for preprocessing source code corpus according to a specified vocabulary modeling choice supported modeling choice are make sure you have python installed in your system pip setuptools and wheel are up to date install codeprep lib in order to run the ronin algorithm you will have to additionally install spiral module http github com casics spiral the tool can be used a a python library a well a a standalone module runnable with a cli you can pas the path to the dataset or the text itself to be preprocessed when using python api for the former option you need to import method from codeprep api text module for the latter from codeprep api corpus below you can see the general pattern of usage python apiclihereafter we will demonstrate the usage a a python library the cli is analogous to the python api you can find the documentation about how to use it here tokenization camelcase and snake case splitting the following code doe camelcase and snake case splitting and applies bpe with k merges on top codeprep by default doe bpe using bpe code leaned on the github java corpus the argument bpe code id k tell the codeprep tool to use bpe merges other possible value are k and k and merges respectively please refer to section learning custom bpe code to train custom bpe code for other command and option like char split number ronin stem please refer to the doc set calc vocab param to true when calling a preprocessing method to calculate the vocabulary of the preprocessed corpus e g if you don t want to use pre trained bpe code it s possible to train custom one for example to train merges on the corpus located at the path path to train on the following command should be run only cli now it is possible to do bpe splitting by running the bpe command with the number of merges from to for example with merges before bpe code are trained the basic preprocessing is done which can also be tuned with argument described in section tweaking preprocessing you can pas the following parameter with a true value default value for all of them are false to tweak the way the imput is preprocessed similar params can be specified a switch no str no com no space no unicode no case in cli command unless explicitely specified codeprep will assume the language is java to make sure the input is preprocessed a intended it is always highly recommended to specify it when preprocessing a corpus codeprep identifies the language based on the file extension if you want only file with a certain extension s to be preprocessed you can specify ext paramyou can specify the path to where the preprocessed corpus will be written to print log with log level debug and higher to stdout to get help on command and option this library wa build to run experiment for our paper accepted at icse big code big vocabulary open vocabulary model for source codeif you you the library or the result please cite the paper when preprocessing a dataset codeprep first par source code and convert it into internal representation which is after that converted to a preprocessed dataset depending on provided parameter the intermediate representation is cached so that when the same dataset is pre processed again with different parameter codeprep providing no change have been made to the dataset would use the cache rather than parsing the source code again to store the cache codeprep us a directory speecified by xdg cache home codeprep codeprep version variable if it value is set home cache codeprep codeprep version otherwise removing the cache will not change the final result however will result in slower pre processing initial pypi release

autocompletion without a running kernelwhen a kernel is available the suggestion from the kernel such a key of a dict and column of a dataframe are merged with the suggestion from the language server in notebook if the kernel is too slow to respond promptly only the language server suggestion will be shown default threshold s you can configure the completer to not attempt to fetch the kernel description: simple python package to sanitize in a standard way ml related label so you have some kind of plot and you have some ml related label since i always rename and sanitize them the same way i have prepared this package to always sanitize them in a standard fashion a usual just download it using pip here you have a couple of common example you have a set of metric to normalize or a set of model name to normalize in some case you may have a combination of term separated by hyphen that must be removed plus word that are actually correctly written separated by hyphen we approach this problem with an heuristic based on an extended list of over k hyphenated english word originally retrieved from the metadata consulting website from such a word list we generate an index by running and from there the user experience is transparent and look a follows the lookup heuristic to quickly find an hyphenated word in a given label from the large haystack wa written by tommaso fontana since i always use metric sanitization alongside axis normalization it is useful to know which axis should be maxed between zero and one to avoid any visualization bias to the metric for this reason i have created the method is normalized metric which after having normalized the given metric validates it against known normalized metric metric between and is there another name i could not figure out a better one analogously i have also created the method is absolutely normalized metric to validate a metric for the range between and a always for new feature and issue you can either open a new issue and pull request a pull request will always be the quicker way but i ll look into the issue when i get the time i have strived to mantain a code coverage in this project modulestatementsmissingexcludedcoveragetotal sanitize ml label init py sanitize ml label version py sanitize ml label is normalized metric py sanitize ml label find true hyphenated word py sanitize ml label sanitize ml label py you can verify the test coverage of this repository by running in it root

description: a fast robust python library to check for profanity or offensive language in string read more about how and why profanity check wa built in this blog post you can also test out profanity check in your browser profanity check us a linear svm model trained on k human labeled sample of clean and profane text string it model is simple but surprisingly effective meaning profanity check is both robust and extremely performant many profanity detection library use a hard coded list of bad word to detect and filter profanity for example profanity us this wordlist and even better profanity still us a wordlist there are obviously glaring issue with this approach and while they might be performant these library are not accurate at all a simple example for which profanity check is better is the phrase you cocksucker profanity think this is clean because it doesn t have cocksucker in it wordlist other library like profanity filter use more sophisticated method that are much more accurate but at the cost of performance a benchmark performed december on a new macbook pro using a kaggle dataset of wikipedia comment yielded roughly the following result profanity check is anywhere from time faster than profanity filter in this benchmark this table speaks for itself see the how section below for more detail on the dataset used for these result note that both predict and predict prob return numpy array special thanks to the author of the datasets used in this project profanity check wa trained on a combined dataset from source profanity check relies heavily on the excellent scikit learn library it s mostly powered by scikit learn class countvectorizer linearsvc and calibratedclassifiercv it us a bag of word model to vectorize input string before feeding them to a linear classifier one simplified way you could think about why profanity check work is this during the training process the model learns which word are bad and how bad they are because those word will appear more often in offensive text thus it s a if the training process is picking out the bad word out of all possible word and using those to make future prediction this is better than just relying on arbitrary word blacklist chosen by human this library is far from perfect for example it ha a hard time picking up on le common variant of swear word like f ck you or you b tch because they don t appear often enough in the training corpus never treat any prediction from this library a unquestionable truth because it doe and will make mistake instead use this library a a heuristic

description: this extension allows you to use python annotation for documenting acceptable argument type and return value type of function see an example of the sphinx render at the pyproject api doc this allows you to use type hint in a very natural fashion allowing you to migrate from this to this first use pip to download and install the extension then add the extension to your conf py the following configuration option are accepted typehints fully qualified default false if true class name are always fully qualified e g module for class if false just the class name display e g class always document param type default false if false do not add type info for undocumented parameter if true add stub documentation for undocumented parameter to be able to add type info typehints document rtype default true if false never add an rtype directive if true add the rtype directive if no existing rtype is found typehints use rtype default true control behavior when typehints document rtype is set to true if true document return type in the rtype directive if false document return type a part of the return directive if present otherwise fall back to using rtype use in conjunction with napoleon use rtype to avoid generation of duplicate or redundant return type information typehints default default none if none default are not added otherwise add a default annotation simplify optional union default true if true optional parameter of type union are simplified a being of type union none in the resulting documentation e g optional union a b union a b none if false the optional type is kept note if false any union containing none will be displayed a optional note if an optional parameter ha only a single type e g optional a or union a none it will always be displayed a optional typehints formatter default none if set to a function this function will be called with annotation a first argument and sphinx config config argument second the function is expected to return a string with restructuredtext code or none to fall back to the default formatter the extension listens to the autodoc process signature and autodoc process docstring sphinx event in the former it strip the annotation from the function signature in the latter it injects the appropriate type argname and rtype directive into the docstring only argument that have an existing param directive in the docstring get their respective type directive added the rtype directive is added if and only if no existing rtype is found to use sphinx ext napoleon with sphinx autodoc typehints make sure you load sphinx ext napoleon first before sphinx autodoc typehints see issue on the issue tracker for more information sometimes function or class from two different module need to reference each other in their type annotation this creates a circular import problem the solution to this is the following on python you can even use from future import annotation and remove the quote if you re documenting code that need to stay compatible with python you cannot use regular type annotation instead you must either be using python or later or have typed ast installed the package extra type comment will pull in the appropriate dependency automatically then you can add type hint comment in the following manner or alternatively

description: python implementation of tdebatty java string similaritya library implementing different string similarity and distance measure a dozen of algorithm including levenshtein edit distance and sibblings jaro winkler longest common subsequence cosine similarity etc are currently implemented check the summary table below for the complete list from pypi or clone this repository the main characteristic of each implemented algorithm are presented below the cost column give an estimation of the computational cost to compute the similarity between two string of length m and n respectively in this library levenshtein edit distance lcs distance and their sibblings are computed using the dynamic programming method which ha a cost o m n for levenshtein distance the algorithm is sometimes called wagner fischer algorithm the string to string correction problem the original algorithm us a matrix of size m x n to store the levenshtein distance between string prefix if the alphabet is finite it is possible to use the method of four russian arlazarov et al on economic construction of the transitive closure of a directed graph to speedup computation this wa published by masek in a faster algorithm computing string edit distance this method split the matrix in block of size t x t each possible block is precomputed to produce a lookup table this lookup table can then be used to compute the string similarity or distance in o nm t usually t is choosen a log m if m n the resulting computation cost is thus o mn log m this method ha not been implemented yet in length of maximal common subsequence k s larsen proposed an algorithm that computes the length of lcs in time o log m log n but the algorithm ha a memory requirement o m n and wa thus not implemented here there are two variant of damerau levenshtein string distance damerau levenshtein with adjacent transposition also sometimes called unrestricted damerau levenshtein distance and optimal string alignment also sometimes called restricted edit distance for optimal string alignment no substring can be edited more than once although the topic might seem simple a lot of different algorithm exist to measure text similarity or distance therefore the library defines some interface to categorize them generally algorithm that implement normalizedstringsimilarity also implement normalizedstringdistance and similarity distance but there are a few exception like n gram similarity and distance kondrak the metricstringdistance interface a few of the distance are actually metric distance which mean that verify the triangle inequality d x y d x z d z y for example levenshtein is a metric distance but normalizedlevenshtein is not a lot of nearest neighbor search algorithm and indexing structure rely on the triangle inequality a few algorithm work by converting string into set of n gram sequence of n character also sometimes called k shingle the similarity or distance between the string is then the similarity or distance between the set some of them like jaccard consider string a set of shingle and don t consider the number of occurences of each shingle others like cosine similarity work using what is sometimes called the profile of the string which take into account the number of occurences of each shingle for these algorithm another use case is possible when dealing with large datasets the levenshtein distance between two word is the minimum number of single character edits insertion deletion or substitution required to change one word into the other it is a metric string distance this implementation us dynamic programming wagner fischer algorithm with only row of data the space requirement is thus o m and the algorithm run in o m n this distance is computed a levenshtein distance divided by the length of the longest string the resulting value is always in the interval but it is not a metric anymore the similarity is computed a normalized distance an implementation of levenshtein that allows to define different weight for different character substitution this algorithm is usually used for optical character recognition ocr application for ocr the cost of substituting p and r is lower then the cost of substituting p and m for example because because from and ocr point of view p is similar to r it can also be used for keyboard typing auto correction here the cost of substituting e and r is lower for example because these are located next to each other on an azerty or qwerty keyboard hence the probability that the user mistyped the character is higher similar to levenshtein damerau levenshtein distance with transposition also sometimes call unrestricted damerau levenshtein distance is the minimum number of operation needed to transform one string into the other where an operation is defined a an insertion deletion or substitution of a single character or a transposition of two adjacent character it doe respect triangle inequality and is thus a metric distance this is not to be confused with the optimal string alignment distance which is an extension where no substring can be edited more than once will produce the optimal string alignment variant of damerau levenshtein sometimes called the restricted edit distance computes the number of edit operation needed to make the string equal under the condition that no substring is edited more than once whereas the true damerau levenshtein present no such restriction the difference from the algorithm for levenshtein distance is the addition of one recurrence for the transposition operation note that for the optimal string alignment distance the triangle inequality doe not hold and so it is not a true metric will produce jaro winkler is a string edit distance that wa developed in the area of record linkage duplicate detection winkler the jaro winkler distance metric is designed and best suited for short string such a person name and to detect typo jaro winkler computes the similarity between string and the returned value lie in the interval it is roughly a variation of damerau levenshtein where the substitution of close character is considered le important then the substitution of character that a far from each other the distance is computed a jaro winkler similarity will produce the longest common subsequence lcs problem consists in finding the longest subsequence common to two or more sequence it differs from problem of finding common substring unlike substring subsequence are not required to occupy consecutive position within the original sequence it is used by the diff utility by git for reconciling multiple change etc the lcs distance between string x of length n and y of length m is n m lcs x y min max n mlcs distance is equivalent to levenshtein distance when only insertion and deletion is allowed no substitution or when the cost of the substitution is the double of the cost of an insertion or deletion this class implement the dynamic programming approach which ha a space requirement o m n and computation cost o m n in length of maximal common subsequence k s larsen proposed an algorithm that computes the length of lcs in time o log m log n but the algorithm ha a memory requirement o m n and wa thus not implemented here distance metric based on longest common subsequence from the note an lcs based string metric by daniel bakkelund http heim ifi uio no danielry stringmetric pdfthe distance is computed a lcs s s max s s will produce normalized n gram distance a defined by kondrak n gram similarity and distance string processing and information retrieval lecture note in computer science volume pp http webdocs c ualberta ca kondrak paper spire pdfthe algorithm us affixing with special character n to increase the weight of first character the normalization is achieved by dividing the total similarity score the original length of the longest word in the paper kondrak also defines a similarity measure which is not implemented yet a few algorithm work by converting string into set of n gram sequence of n character also sometimes called k shingle the similarity or distance between the string is then the similarity or distance between the set the cost for computing these similarity and distance is mainly domnitated by k shingling converting the string into sequence of k character therefore there are typically two use case for these algorithm directly compute the distance between string or for large datasets pre compute the profile of all string the similarity can then be computed between profile pay attention this only work if the same kshingling object is used to parse all input string q gram distance a defined by ukkonen in approximate string matching with q gram and maximal match http www sciencedirect com science article pii the distance between two string is defined a the l norm of the difference of their profile the number of occurences of each n gram sum v i v i q gram distance is a lower bound on levenshtein distance but can be computed in o m n where levenshtein requires o m n the similarity between the two string is the cosine of the angle between these two vector representation and is computed a v v v v distance is computed a cosine similarity like q gram distance the input string are first converted into set of n gram sequence of n character also called k shingle but this time the cardinality of each n gram is not taken into account each input string is simply a set of n gram the jaccard index is then computed a v inter v v union v distance is computed a similarity jaccard index is a metric distance similar to jaccard index but this time the similarity is computed a v inter v v v distance is computed a similarity sift is a general purpose string distance algorithm inspired by jarowinkler and longest common subsequence it wa developed to produce a distance measure that match a close a possible to the human perception of string distance hence it take into account element like character substitution character distance longest common subsequence etc it wa developed using experimental testing and without theoretical background not implemented yetuse java string similarity in your project and want it to be mentioned here don t hesitate to drop me a line

description: lexrank algorithm for text summarizationlexrank is an unsupervised approach to text summarization based on graph based centrality scoring of sentence the main idea is that sentence recommend other similar sentence to the reader thus if one sentence is very similar to many others it will likely be a sentence of great importance the importance of this sentence also stem from the importance of the sentence recommending it thus to get ranked highly and placed in a summary a sentence must be similar to many sentence that are in turn also similar to many other sentence this make intuitive sense and allows the algorithm to be applied to any arbitrary new text in the following example we use bbc news dataset a a corpus of document stop word for language are included into the package to define your own mapping of stop word prepare text file with utf encoding where word are separated by newlines then use the commandthat replaces the default mapping note that name of txt file are used a key in stopwords dictionary test are not supplied with the package to run them you need to clone the repository and install additional dependency run linter and testsg ne erkan and dragomir r radev lexrank graph based lexical centrality a salience in text summarization

description: this is a python api which allows you to get the transcript subtitle for a given youtube video it also work for automatically generated subtitle support translating subtitle and it doe not require a headless browser like other selenium based solution do it is recommended to install this module by using pip if you want to use it from source you ll have to install the dependency manually you can either integrate this module into an existing application or just use it via an cli the easiest way to get a transcript for a given video is to execute this will return a list of dictionary looking somewhat like this you can also add the language param if you want to make sure the transcript are retrieved in your desired language it default to english it s a list of language code in a descending priority in this example it will first try to fetch the german transcript de and then fetch the english transcript en if it fails to do so if you want to find out which language are available first have a look at list transcript to get transcript for a list of video id you can call language also is optional here if you want to list all transcript which are available for a given video you can call this will return a transcriptlist object which is iterable and provides method to filter the list of transcript for specific language and type like by default this module always pick manually created transcript over automatically created one if a transcript in the requested language is available both manually created and generated the transcriptlist allows you to bypass this default behaviour by searching for specific transcript type the method find generated transcript find manually created transcript find generated transcript return transcript object they contain metadata regarding the transcript and provide the method which allows you to fetch the actual transcript data youtube ha a feature which allows you to automatically translate subtitle this module also make it possible to access this feature to do so transcript object provide a translate method which return a new translated transcript object formatters are meant to be an additional layer of processing of the transcript you pas it the goal is to convert the transcript from it python data type into a consistent string of a given format such a a basic text txt or even format that have a defined specification such a json json webvtt vtt srt srt comma separated format csv etc the formatters submodule provides a few basic formatters to wrap around you transcript data in case where you might want to do something such a output a specific format then write that format to a file maybe to backup store and run another script against at a later time we provided a few subclass of formatters to use here is how to import from the formatters module let say we wanted to retrieve a transcript and write that transcript a a json file in the same format a the api returned it a that would look something like this passing extra keyword argumentssince jsonformatter leverage json dump you can also forward keyword argument into format transcript transcript such a making your file output prettier by forwarding the indent keyword argument you can implement your own formatter class just inherit from the formatter base class and ensure you implement the format transcript self transcript kwargs and format transcript self transcript kwargs method which should ultimately return a string when called on your formatter instance execute the cli script using the video id a parameter and the result will be printed out to the command line the cli also give you the option to provide a list of preferred language you can also specify if you want to exclude automatically generated or manually created subtitle if you would prefer to write it into a file or pipe it into another application you can also output the result a json using the following line translating transcript using the cli is also possible if you are not sure which language are available for a given video you can call to list all available transcript if a video s id start with a hyphen you ll have to mask the hyphen using to prevent the cli from mistaking it for a argument name for example to get the transcript for the video with the id abc run you can specify a http proxy which will be used during the request to youtube a the proxy dict is passed on to the request get call it follows the format used by the request library using the cli some video are age restricted so this module won t be able to access those video without some sort of authentication to do this you will need to have access to the desired video in a browser then you will need to download that page cooky into a text file you can use the chrome extension cooky txt or the firefox extension cooky txt once you have that you can use it with the module to access age restricted video caption like so using the cli this code us an undocumented part of the youtube api which is called by the youtube web client so there is no guarantee that it won t stop working tomorrow if they change how thing work i will however do my best to make thing working again a soon a possible if that happens so if it stop working let me know if this project make you happy by reducing your development time you can make me happy by treating me to a cup of coffee

description: keybert is a minimal and easy to use keyword extraction technique that leverage bert embeddings to create keywords and keyphrases that are most similar to a document corresponding medium post can be found here back to tocalthough there are already many method available for keyword generation e g rake yake tf idf etc i wanted to create a very basic but powerful method for extracting keywords and keyphrases this is where keybert come in which us bert embeddings and simple cosine similarity to find the sub phrase in a document that are the most similar to the document itself first document embeddings are extracted with bert to get a document level representation then word embeddings are extracted for n gram word phrase finally we use cosine similarity to find the word phrase that are the most similar to the document the most similar word could then be identified a the word that best describe the entire document keybert is by no mean unique and is created a a quick and easy method for creating keywords and keyphrases although there are many great paper and solution out there that use bert embeddings e g i could not find a bert based solution that did not have to be trained from scratch and could be used for beginner correct me if i m wrong thus the goal wa a pip install keybert and at most line of code in usage back to tocinstallation can be done using pypi you may want to install more depending on the transformer and language backends that you will be using the possible installation are the most minimal example can be seen below for the extraction of keywords you can set keyphrase ngram range to set the length of the resulting keywords keyphrases to extract keyphrases simply set keyphrase ngram range to or higher depending on the number of word you would like in the resulting keyphrases we can highlight the keywords in the document by simply setting highlight note for a full overview of all possible transformer model see sentence transformer i would advise either all minilm l v for english document or paraphrase multilingual minilm l v for multi lingual document or any other language to diversify the result we take the x top n most similar word phrase to the document then we take all top n combination from the x top n word and extract the combination that are the least similar to each other by cosine similarity to diversify the result we can use maximal margin relevance mmr to create keywords keyphrases which is also based on cosine similarity the result with high diversity the result with low diversity keybert support many embedding model that can be used to embed the document and word click here for a full overview of all supported embedding model sentence transformer you can select any model from sentence transformer here and pas it through keybert with model or select a sentencetransformer model with your own parameter flair flair allows you to choose almost any embedding model that is publicly available flair description: labelled data remains a scarce resource in many practical nlp scenario this is especially the case when working with resource poor language or text domain or when using task specific label without pre existing datasets the only available option is often to collect and annotate text by hand which is expensive and time consuming skweak pronounced skwi k is a python based software toolkit that provides a concrete solution to this problem using weak supervision skweak is built around a very simple idea instead of annotating text by hand we define a set of labelling function to automatically label our document and then aggregate their result to obtain a labelled version of our corpus the labelling function may take various form such a domain specific heuristic like pattern matching rule gazetteer based on large dictionary machine learning model or even annotation from crowd worker the aggregation is done using a statistical model that automatically estimate the relative accuracy and confusion of each labelling function by comparing their prediction with one another skweak can be applied to both sequence labelling and text classification and come with a complete api that make it possible to create apply and aggregate labelling function with just a few line of code the toolkit is also tightly integrated with spacy which make it easy to incorporate into existing nlp pipeline give it a try full paper pierre lison jeremy barnes and aliaksandr hubin skweak weak supervision made easy for nlp acl system demonstration documentation api see the wiki for detail on how to use skweak http user image githubusercontent com e ea eb bb dc e mp you also need python the easiest way to install skweak is through pip or if you want to install from the repo the above installation only includes the core library not the additional example in example note some example and test may require trained spacy pipeline these can be downloaded automatically using the syntax for the pipeline en core web sm weak supervision with skweak go through the following step here is a minimal example with three labelling function lf applied on a single document obviously to get the most out of skweak you will need more than three labelling function and most importantly you will need a larger corpus including a many document a possible from your domain so that the model can derive good estimate of the relative accuracy of each labelling function see the wiki skweak is released under an mit license the mit license is a short and simple permissive license allowing both commercial and non commercial use of the software the only requirement is to preserve the copyright and license notice see file license licensed work modification and larger work may be distributed under different term and without source code see our paper describing the framework pierre lison jeremy barnes and aliaksandr hubin skweak weak supervision made easy for nlp acl system demonstration

description: nb segtok v code named syntok is available and fix some tricky issue with segtok in particular splitting sentence with terminal not followed by space like this the segtok package provides two module segtok segmenter and segtok tokenizer the segmenter provides functionality for splitting indo european text into sentence the tokenizer provides functionality for splitting indo european sentence into word and symbol collectively called token both module can also be used from the command line while other indo european language could work it ha only been designed with language such a spanish english and german in mind for a more informed introduction to this tool please read the article on my blog to use this package you minimally should have the latest version of python or any branch installed the package is expected to work with both python and tested against those latest python branch a well a python the easiest way to get segtok installed is using pip or any other package manager that work with pypi important if you are on a linux machine and have problem installing the regex dependency of segtok make sure you have the python dev and or python dev package installed to get the necessary header to compile the package then try the command line tool on some plain text file e g this readme to see if segtok meet your need the testing environment work with pytest tox and pyenv you first need to install pyenv on osx with homebrew brew install pyenv and tox with pytest pip install tox pytest configuring pyenv depends on the python version you have installed here we assume you have the latest and version installed and only need to provide an environment for testing segtok against the branch the second command is essential and indicates that your preferred python binary is the system version and then the branch if you forget the second command you will see error like error invocationerror failed to get version info for python pyenv python command not found when running tox if you only have one python version installed say to fully run the test you must also install and globally configure the other version e g the latest x with pyenv too finally to run all of segtok s unit test suite just run tox for detail please refer to the respective documentation this readme only provides an overview of the provided functionality after installing the package two command line tool will be available segmenter and tokenizer each can take utf encoded plain text and transforms it into newline separated sentence or token respectively you can use other encoding in python simply by reconfiguring your environment encoding or in any version of python by forcing a particular encoding with the encoding parameter the tokenizer assumes that each line contains at most one single sentence which is the output format of the segmenter to learn more about each tool please invoke them with their help option h or help this module provides several split function to segment text into list of sentence in addition to unix linebreaks normalizes linebreaks including the unicode linebreak to newline control character n the function rewrite line separator can be used to move rewrite the newline separator in the input text so that they are placed at the sentence segmentation location this module provides several tokenizer function to tokenize input sentence into word and symbol to get the full functionality use the web tokenizer which will split everything semantically correctly except for url and e mail address in addition it provides convenience functionality for english text two compiled pattern is can be used to detect if a word token contains a possessive s marker frank s or is an apostrophe based contraction didn t token that match these pattern can then be split using the split possessive marker and split contraction function respectively license mitcopyright c florian leitner all right reserved contributor kudos mikhail korobov kmike port to python and travis ci integration georg kucsko gkucsko splitting sentence at terminal followed by noise karthikeyan singaravelan tirkarthi removing deprecation warning primo godec primozgodec fixed license file in setup py setup py renamed data file with the license txt file reference to license file removed deprecation warning a well a support for python from tox added the license a a license txt file to this repository enhancement split sentence even if the terminal is followed by invalid character contributed by gkucsko fixed a bug that would lead to joining line in single line mode reported by yucongo support for middle name initial lester p pearson also support for european style number date with numeric month added support for european style number date and for month dez fixed a tokenizer bug when parsing url ending with root path prevented sentence splitting after u k u s and e u if followed by upper case u s air force added missing unicode hyphen and apostrophe and added test suite setup instruction removed count continuation py discussion from readme wa only confusing the segmenter now can preserve tab separated text id before the text itself when reading from stdin and then insert a tab separated sentence id column for each sentence printed to stdout see segmenter option with id continuation word have been statistically evaluated and some poor choice removed leading to more precise sentence splitting see issue by klim on github the word tokenizer no longer split on colon between digit time reference fixed multiple dangling comma and colon reported by jim geovedi added python support and travis ci test integration big thanks to mikhail made segtok tokenizer match protected renamed to match and fixed unix linebreak normalization the length of sentence inside bracket is now parametrized wrote blog documentation and added chemical formula sub super script functionality fixed unicode list of valid sentence terminal wa missing u fixed pypi setup missing manifest in for readme rst and package in setup py added possessive s marker and apostrophe contraction splitting of token initial release

description: not only is nerda a mesmerizing muppet like character nerda is also a python package that offer a slick easy to use interface for fine tuning pretrained transformer for named entity recognition ner task you can also utilize nerda to access a selection of precooked nerda model that you can use right off the shelf for ner task nerda is built on huggingface transformer and the popular pytorch framework nerda can be installed from pypi withif you want the development version then install directly from github named entity recognition ner also known a named entity identification entity chunking and entity extraction is a subtask of information extraction that seek to locate and classify named entity mentioned in unstructured text into pre defined category such a person name organization location medical code time expression quantity monetary value percentage etc taskidentify person name and organization in text jim bought share of acme corp solutionread more about ner on wikipedia say we want to fine tune a pretrained multilingual bert transformer for ner in english load package instantiate a nerda model with default setting for the conll english ner data set by default the network architecture is analogous to that of the model in hvingelby et al the model can then be trained fine tuned by invoking the train method e g note this will take some time depending on the dimension of your machine if you want to skip training you can go ahead and use one of the model that we have already precooked for you in stead after the model ha been trained the model can be used for predicting named entity in new text this mean that the model identified old macdonald a a person please note that the nerda model configuration above wa instantiated with all default setting you can however customize your nerda model in a lot of way read more about advanced usage of nerda in the detailed documentation we have precooked a number of nerda model for danish and english that you can download and use right off the shelf here is an example instantiate a multilingual bert model that ha been finetuned for ner in danish da bert ml down load network from web you can now predict named entity in new danish textsthe table below show the precooked nerda model publicly available for download f score is the micro averaged f score across entity tag and is evaluated on the respective test set that have not been used for training nor validation of the model note that we have not spent a lot of time on actually fine tuning the model so there could be room for improvement if you are able to improve the model we will be happy to hear from you and include your nerda model the table below summarizes the performance f score of the precooked nerda model nerda originally stand for named entity recognition for danish however this is somewhat misleading since the functionality is no longer limited to danish on the contrary it generalizes to all other language i e nerda support fine tuning of transformer for ner task for any arbitrary language nerda is developed a a part of ekstra bladet s activity on platform intelligence in news pin pin is an industrial research project that is carried out in collaboration between the technical university of denmark university of copenhagen and copenhagen business school with funding from innovation fund denmark the project run from and develops recommender system and natural language processing system geared for news publishing some of which are open sourced like nerda the detailed documentation for nerda including code reference and extended workflow example can be accessed here we hope that you will find nerda useful please direct any question and feedback to u if you want to contribute which we encourage you to open a pr if you encounter a bug or want to suggest an enhancement please open an issue

description: easily compute clip embeddings and build a clip retrieval system with them m text image embeddings can be processed in h using a end to end this make it possible to build a simple semantic search system interested to learn about semantic search in general you can read my medium post on the topic also see laion b and semantic search at billion scale to read more on how to make this scale to billion of sample pip install clip retrievalclipclient allows remote querying of a clip retrieval backend via python see clipclient getting started notebook for a jupyter notebook example during initialization you can specify a few parameter for instance to query the hosted backend for laion b with the default parameter you can find captioned image similar to the text you provide you can also find captioned image similar to the image you provide image can be passed via local path or url you can also find captioned image similar to a clip embedding you provide to enhance an existing dataset with similar text image pair you can query a directory of image and combine the result you can create a dataset using the saved json result and the tool img dataset first pick a dataset of image url and caption example then run you may want to run export cuda visible device to avoid using your gpu if it doesn t have enough vram then go to http localhost and enjoy searching among your picturesuse run back false if you don t want to run the backendget some image in an example folder for example by doing you can also put text file with the same name a the image in that folder to get the text embeddings then run clip retrieval inference input dataset image folder output folder embeddings folderoutput folder will contain this scale to million of sample at sample s of a m sample can be processed in h clip inference turn a set of text image into clip embeddingsif you wish to have more control over how inference is run you can create and call worker directly using clip retrieval inference workerexample usage doing so will invoke a single worker that can be instructed to focus on a specific subset of the input dataset that worker will sequentially process the task passed to it here task is a list of partition id s that this worker will be responsible for to manually compute the number of task use the following formula number sample wds number file per input file the api is very similar to clip retrieval inference with some minor change note the worker doe not accept the following argumentsexample of hdfs query using webdataset format clip inference input dataset pipe hdfs dfs cat myfolder webdataset tar output folder hdfs myfolder embeddings input format webdataset clip inference input dataset pipe aws s cp quiet s myfolder webdataset tar output folder s myfolder embeddings input format webdatasetto run this on multiple node and multiple gpus see tutorial at doc distributed clip inference mdclip index take a input the output of clip inference and make an index out of it using autofaissclip retrieval index embeddings folder embeddings folder index folder index folderthe output is a folder containing thanks to autofaiss and faiss this scale to hundred of million of sample in a few hour you may want to carefully pick how much memory to use for your index in order to maximize the knn recall autofaiss index selection colab can help along with autofaiss score index command to check the recall of your index in general index using more memory get a better recall and hence are closer to a naive slow knnonce the embeddings are computed you may want to filter out the data by a specific query for that you can run clip retrieval filter query cat output folder cat indice folder indice folder it will copy the best image for this query in the output folder using the num result or threshold may be helpful to refine the filterthanks to fast knn index this can run in real time m for large k value and in minute for very large k value this script work for small datasets for larger one please check notebook simple filter ipynb clip back is a simple knn service backend if using both hdf and faiss memory mapping it us only the memory used by clip which is gb run output folder is the output of clip index option these option can also be provided in the config file to have different option for each index example hdf or arrow caching is a good idea to use if at this point you have a simple flask server running on port and that can answer these query text image and image url are mutually exclusive and return each object may also contain an url field if the metadata provides it the id is the position of the item in the index it may be used to query metadata with the metadata endpoint which return num result id argument of knn service and metadata can be used together to do large knn query and then fetch the metadata only when needed it make sense to do that a knn search can be very efficient thanks to strong locality of reference of knn ivf index making it fast to do knn with a large k whereas the current on disk implementation of metadata hdf doe not have that property and hence cannot handle retrieving a large amount of random item fast in particular this can be used to implement infinite scroll in a front end by default the backend will also expose a front end that front end will by default hit this backend however you may need to specify whether this is happening over http or http in this case use the option default backend to specify the backend url url column allows specifying the name of the column url for the frontthis backends ha a m latency if using memory mapped index and metadata throughput is about query s for high throughput using a grpc server is required a well a a gpu for fast clip inference turning off memory mapping option can also speed up request at the cost of high ram usage this backends also expose a prometheus metric endpoint a well a an human readable summary at metric summary this can optionally be used to setup a grafana dashboard for monitoring it can be seen on this dashboard that the slowest part of any call is fetching the image by it url in case of image url search taking up to m for text query or image query the latency is about m here is an example of output in the metric summary clip front is a simple ui that connects to clip back and display the result you can use it at clip retrieval uior you can run it yourself with you can also run it with clip retrieval front or back from the python package for development it go to front and run npm install then npm start either locally or in gitpod do export pip user false there setup a virtualenv to run test thenyou can use make black to reformat the codepython m pytest x s v test k test runner description: a textblob sentiment analysis pipeline component for spacy install spacytextblob from pypi textblob requires additional data to be downloaded before getting started spacy also requires that you download a model to get started spacytextblob allows you to access all of the attribute created of the textblob textblob class but within the spacy framework the code below will demonstrate how to use spacytextblob on a simple string in comparison here is how the same code would look using textblob spacytextblob performs sentiment analysis using the textblob library adding spacytextblob to a spacy nlp pipeline creates a new extension attribute for the doc span and token class from spacy the blob attribute contains all of the method and attribute that belong to the textblob textblob class some of the common method and attribute include see the textblob doc for the complete listing of all attribute and method that are available in blob
